title: Interval Estimation for Proportions
contentHtml:
When estimating a population proportion, we often rely on interval estimation techniques to provide a range of plausible values. In this concept, we'll explore the basics of confidence intervals (CIs) for proportions and discuss the normal approximation method.

A CI for a proportion is a range of values within which the true population proportion lies with a certain level of confidence. This is particularly important in machine learning and AI applications where we need to quantify uncertainty and make informed decisions.
intuition: The key insight is that the normal approximation method provides a simple and efficient way to construct CIs for proportions, especially when the sample size is large.
realWorldApplications: Estimating the effectiveness of a marketing campaign

subject: statistics
title: Interval Estimation for Proportions
contentHtml:
When estimating a population proportion, we often rely on interval estimation techniques to provide a range of plausible values.

The Wilson interval is a popular method that combines the normal approximation with continuity correction. In this card, we'll explore the intuition behind CI for proportions and its applications in machine learning.
intuition: The Wilson interval cleverly adjusts the normal approximation to account for the discrete nature of proportions. By using a continuity correction, we ensure that our confidence intervals are more accurate and reliable.
realWorldApplications: Estimating the effectiveness of A/B testing in machine learning
commonMistakes: Failing to consider the continuity correction when applying the Wilson interval

subject: statistics
title: Interval Estimation for Proportions
contentHtml:
In statistics, we often need to estimate a population proportion based on a random sample from that population. One way to do this is by constructing an interval estimate, also known as a confidence interval (CI). The CI for proportions provides a range of values within which the true population proportion lies.

The normal approximation method and exact methods are two common approaches to construct CIs for proportions. The Wilson interval is another popular method that combines the strengths of both approaches.
intuition: The CI for proportions provides a range of values within which the true population proportion lies. This helps us quantify our uncertainty and make more informed decisions.
realWorldApplications: Estimating the effectiveness of a marketing campaign
